Answer: I need to correct the OP’s terminology: to start a new paragraph we use what's called aLikethis.When we do not want to start a new paragraph, but we do want to start a new line it's called aWith a normal keyI need to correct the OP’s terminology: to start a new paragraph we use what's called aLikethis.When we do not want to start a new paragraph, but we do want to start a new line it's called aWith a normal keyboard this is no real issue. You just hit both keys simultaneously. With the mobile app and just a touch screen it is a problem.But I'm usingUsing Ginger I can easily hit <shift> first and subsequently hit the <enter> key. Using my standard Samsung keyboard this does not work.I'm not affiliated with Ginger, but the main reason why I use it is because it has a dictionary in (US and UK) English, French, and Dutch: the languages I tend to use. You can switch easily between different languages. (No auto-detect though.) Downside for me is that the layout is QWERTY and not AZERTY. Only very few countries use AZERTY, but Belgium is one of them. For a real keyboard it would be a show stopper, but for a touchscreen it's doable.

Answer: Alright, I asked this question and my answer isn’t as satisfying as I would like, but I have figured out a way.Over the course of my year on Quora, I have typed approximately four Answers on my computer and I use my Android and iPad almost exclusively. There were times that I wrote an answer and saved it as a draft, just so that I could single-space it on my computer later on. The whole process was very frustrating. As far as I can tell, there still isn’t an easy way for most mobile users to single-space…but there is one way, and it is both obnoxious and requires monetary commitment.NonethelesAlright, I asked this question and my answer isn’t as satisfying as I would like, but I have figured out a way.Over the course of my year on Quora, I have typed approximately four Answers on my computer and I use my Android and iPad almost exclusively. There were times that I wrote an answer and saved it as a draft, just so that I could single-space it on my computer later on. The whole process was very frustrating. As far as I can tell, there still isn’t an easy way for most mobile users to single-space…but there is one way, and it is both obnoxious and requires monetary commitment.Nonetheless, I am currently writing this answer on the Quora mobile app on my iPad, and I can still single-space.So here is the only alternative I have found, and remember that I warned you about how shite it is.Bluetooth KeyboardYup, it’s that lame of a solution.Since I know that everyone on Quora is super-duper-interested in my personal life, my iPad’s cover recently tore and I was required to purchase a new case today. Instead of buying the normal, cheap cover (except that it’s Apple, so cheap is a distinctly relative term) I bought a snooty, super-rich-guy case with built-in Bluetooth keyboard (just ’cause I’m baller like that), and was shocked to find that shift+enter on my Bluetooth keyboard makes a single space. Hooray!So, if you write Quora on your phone or tablet, all you need to do to be able to single-space is to buy a new keyboard.But here’s the (marginally) good news: If you already own a Bluetooth keyboard, you can probably use that. I have never tried to hook a Bluetooth keyboard up to a phone, but I see no reason why it couldn’t be done, and as soon as you have those keys, you can single-space yourself silly.IP.S. My Bluetooth keyboard cost

Answer: The C++ standard library and ecosystem is bad. Really bad.Take something like Python:When people say C++ is hard to write, they generally don’t think about library support.Yes, debugging C++ is far harder as you don’t get nice, neat stack traces telling you exactly where you went wrong. Yes, manually being in charge of stuff like references and consThe C++ standard library and ecosystem is bad. Really bad.Take something like Python:When people say C++ is hard to write, they generally don’t think about library support.Yes, debugging C++ is far harder as you don’t get nice, neat stack traces telling you exactly where you went wrong. Yes, manually being in charge of stuff like references and const-correctness can be tricky in the beginning. This all matters less with experience.It’s definitely not because of “muh pOiNtErS” or whatever. Memory management with RAII and smart pointers is trivial. Even if it did require C-style memory management, it’s still something that becomes easier with experience.You know whatAlmost all other mainstream languages actually have support for common things that developers use all the time.C++ has none of these things.JSON support? Non-existent.HTTP? Hah! Do you know how long it took me to find this:Date and time handling? Nowhere to be found. No, std::chrono doesn’t count.String handling? C++ doesn’t even have a split() function! What language doesn’t have something so trivial?Oh, sure, C++ has arcane stuff like “std::back_inserter” but Satan forbid the committee add something as trivial as “std::string.split()”.Yes, hardly anyone needs the raw speed and low memory footprint of C++ when developing web applications. Answer: I started learning computer science and programming with C/C++. It was so much fun to create small command line programs and implement various algorithms. In my opinion, C is great to understand the concept of programming and C++ for OOP. These two are such great languages for systems programming and I wouldn’t be wrong in saying without C, there is no operating system.However when it comes to web based applications level programming, I find some qualities of C/C++ to have significant scopes of improvement:1. Low level-nessI started learning computer science and programming with C/C++. It was so much fun to create small command line programs and implement various algorithms. In my opinion, C is great to understand the concept of programming and C++ for OOP. These two are such great languages for systems programming and I wouldn’t be wrong in saying without C, there is no operating system.However when it comes to web based applications level programming, I find some qualities of C/C++ to have significant scopes of improvement:1. Low level-ness2. Lack of an industry grade 3-tier stack (framework)3. Syntax4. Playing with pointersone more because, well… pointers!5. Manual control6. New technologiesDon’t get me wrong, I do like C/C++ without which nothing new could ever happen in computer industry. In fact, there are other places it is used - internet browsers, computer vision tools, heck even Windows OS is written in C++. I would just try to research which language is best for what purpose before making a decision.

Answer: The real question should have beenMajor websites likeC++ is known for its blazing fast speed. Facebook used to convert PHP code to C++ and then compile it into bytecode for increasing the speed of web page generation. But their HipHop compiler (written partly in C++) has since been retooThe real question should have beenMajor websites likeC++ is known for its blazing fast speed. Facebook used to convert PHP code to C++ and then compile it into bytecode for increasing the speed of web page generation. But their HipHop compiler (written partly in C++) has since been retooled as a bytecode virtual machine.There's a Qt-inspired toolkit for developing web applications with C++ calledAny programming language that can parse strings can be used in CGI or a servlet. Any language that can implement bindings with C libraries can also be used to develop modules for ISAPI- or Apache-compatible serversIt's not particularly easy in C++, and good templating engines are few and far between, but it can be done. You need to write a ton of code for setting up a server in C++ while you can start a static file server running in Python in just one line of Code. C++ was not made by keeping web development in mind.The Web didn't even exist when C++ came out in 1979.

Answer: I’m only gonna talk about Spartan 1’s, 2’s and 3’s because I don’t know enough about the restAlso before I begin, my idea of a Spartan 1 is like what SGM Johnson was. Apparently he was some kind of early Spartan. If I’m getting this wrong, please correct (and teach) meSpartan 1:Spartan 1’s are like one step above normal soldiers. Nowhere near the powerhouses the 2’s are. Their Warhammer 40k equivalent would be an Imperial Guardsmen. Elite soldiers with special training that face the horrors of the galaxy and come out on top.Vs the might of the Space Marines.Let’s quickly go over the stats of tI’m only gonna talk about Spartan 1’s, 2’s and 3’s because I don’t know enough about the restAlso before I begin, my idea of a Spartan 1 is like what SGM Johnson was. Apparently he was some kind of early Spartan. If I’m getting this wrong, please correct (and teach) meSpartan 1:Spartan 1’s are like one step above normal soldiers. Nowhere near the powerhouses the 2’s are. Their Warhammer 40k equivalent would be an Imperial Guardsmen. Elite soldiers with special training that face the horrors of the galaxy and come out on top.Vs the might of the Space Marines.Let’s quickly go over the stats of the Space Marines:Ok now for the match ups:In 40k lore, a small squad of Guardsmen can kill a chaos space marine with little to no trouble. However this is due to their Lasgun rifles being stupidly powerful (when used properly) & the Guard having entire combat doctrines dedicated to fighting Space Marines.Spartan 1’s are no doubt skilled combatants. However their standard 7.62 rifles are not able to penetrate even the weakest Astartes armor, nor would they have any training or readiness for the combat situation.I believe it would take anywhere from 20–30 Spartan 1’s to take a Space Marine down. Whether it be one of them grabs a heavy weapon like a Rocket Launcher and the marine can’t dodge in time and gets hit. However even then the marine can take about 3 rockets before he drops. Of the 20–30 Spartans, I believe at least 15 of them will be killed in the process. However the marine may very well kill them all.Now for Spartan 2’s.I like to call these guys Mini Space Marines. VERY impressive soldiers.When comparing a Spartan 2 to a Space Marine, think of the Space Marine’s stats but worse. Space Marines are bigger, stronger, smarter, (sometimes) faster, their armor and weapons are FAR superior.I believe it would take 4–5 Spartan 2’s to take down a Space Marine, my reason for this (for that one idiot that’s gonna leave a comment going “NO A SINGLE SPARTAN 2 CAN LITERALLY KILL EVERY SPACE MARINE EVER REEEEEEEEE” )Yeah sure and Master Chief can kill the Emperor.Anyway, Let’s take the fight with Atriox in Halo Wars 2.3 Spartan 2’s got their asses annihilated by this guy. Atriox only letting them go for… plot? I think he was looking for their base or something idkThe point is Atriox toyed with them, taunted them, let them go. A Space Marine wouldn’t do any of those things. First and foremost, Space Marines would shit on Atriox. I made a post about that a while ago if anyone wants to find the question.Secondly, as said, the Marine wouldn’t waste his time with talk, or staring down his foes. The Spartans would not have gotten the chance to gain their bearings or even comprehend what is going on. Placing a Marine in place of Atriox, the fight would’ve lasted seconds at most.So with that in mind, also realize Spartan 2’s have the same issue the 1’s have. Their standard issue rifles would have no effect on the marine’s armor. They’d have to punch, kick, and use anti tank weaponry like the Spartan Laser & Rocket Launcher to kill the marine.Assuming 6 Spartans meet the marine in a fight, I believe they would take him down. However I also believe at least 1/2 of those Spartans would die.As powerful as the 2’s are, they’re no match for the Space Marines.As for the 3’s:They’re downgraded 2’s. Same issues with the weapons, to keep it quick:10 Spartan 3’s meet the marine, I think at least 5 of them would die. Maybe closer to 6–7.Conclusion:Spartans are VERY powerful soldiers. They’re very cool soldiers! But you gotta remember 2 things:1: Halo is a universe about humanity’s last stand. Spartans were made to give humanity a chance against a relentless onslaught(shut up about the real purpose of Spartans I don’t care about the rebellions)2: In Warhammer 40k, humanity IS the relentless onslaught. Space Marines are made to kill Aliens twenty stories high, demons, and god like beings.Of course the Spartan’s aren’t gonna stand a chance. They’re not supposed to! That doesn’t make Spartans weak, it’s just that Space Marines are so over the top and wacky that it’s not even fair comparing the two.

Answer: Totally depends, against spartan II’s it would probably take three. 4’s would need 10+.II’s are very similar to the space marine in psyche, bred for murder and mayhem, while 4’s are very human, possessing the psychological traits that space marines dislike and that Spartan II’s simply can't understand, they are inferior to II’s, so I will exclude them from this analysis, suffice to say that 4’s can't stand on that level.II’s are powerful, not as powerful as space marines though. A spartan is capable of flipping an elephant over after it has flipped onto its side, meaning that they are powerfulTotally depends, against spartan II’s it would probably take three. 4’s would need 10+.II’s are very similar to the space marine in psyche, bred for murder and mayhem, while 4’s are very human, possessing the psychological traits that space marines dislike and that Spartan II’s simply can't understand, they are inferior to II’s, so I will exclude them from this analysis, suffice to say that 4’s can't stand on that level.II’s are powerful, not as powerful as space marines though. A spartan is capable of flipping an elephant over after it has flipped onto its side, meaning that they are powerful. They are also durable, possessing shields that regenerate and powerful armor. I know it is dumb to say, but the master chief detonated a nuke a stones throw from himself, only to survive and walk it off. Spartans do not get credit for their survivability.Space marines are often trained from birth to fight and have blessed weaponry, and while I am inclined to note the spartan’s weaponry, it would never stack up one on one, but they possess the weapons to break space marine armor. Spartans are also usually best when in teams, even with regular soldiers instead of other Spartans. They fight best that way and they are essentially fearless.The problem with space marines is that they are cocky, thinking of themselves as higher up than regular humans, whereas Spartans don't in the big picture, even if some hold space marine style views.All you need is some good teamwork, good firepower, and the Spartans could do it casualty free.

Answer: Assuming both have standard issue gear (tactical marine vs standard loadout Spartans)? A single 4 to 6 man squad could do the job, potentially casualty free if they’ve got time to plan. Spartans have reaction times easily on par with the Eldar in the fluff and they have extensive close combat training, not enough to confidently take on the Space Marine in CQC simply due to the Space Marine’s dramatically greater emphasis on that area of combat as well as his power armor and chainsword but definitely enough to not be ground to bloody paste the moment that chainsword gets within 3 feet of them,Assuming both have standard issue gear (tactical marine vs standard loadout Spartans)? A single 4 to 6 man squad could do the job, potentially casualty free if they’ve got time to plan. Spartans have reaction times easily on par with the Eldar in the fluff and they have extensive close combat training, not enough to confidently take on the Space Marine in CQC simply due to the Space Marine’s dramatically greater emphasis on that area of combat as well as his power armor and chainsword but definitely enough to not be ground to bloody paste the moment that chainsword gets within 3 feet of them, likely enough to survive and get away actually. The huge, huge advantage that the Space Marine has is that the Spartans are armed with MA5 assault rifles firing modern-day 7.62 ammunition. In other words, it makes the basic lasgun look like an unstoppable rape machine and may as well fire jelly beans by WH40k standards. However, it IS powerful enough to (eventually) bring the Space Marine down with concentrated fire to the joints, which the Spartans are more than capable of pulling off with professionalism and ease in most any given situation. Nonetheless if the Space Marine can draw a solid bead on one of the Spartans with his boltgun, then that Spartan is incapacitated at absolute best and is in fact most likely very, very dead. Thus, more concealing terrain more and more favors the Spartans.

Answer: I’m answering a lot of Halo/ 40k questions today!Spartans are basically mini space marines.on top of that, Space Marines have already encountered many foes similar to Spartans. One example being during the Great Crusade.The Blood Angels encountered a planet ran similarly to the Imperium, however refused to cooperate. The Blood Angels deployed planetwide and begun their attack only to discover the military occupants had genetically modified Warriors of their own.In essence, it was the Blood Angels vs Spartan 3 equivalents.The battle lasted a while and the Blood Angels, while not suffering too mI’m answering a lot of Halo/ 40k questions today!Spartans are basically mini space marines.on top of that, Space Marines have already encountered many foes similar to Spartans. One example being during the Great Crusade.The Blood Angels encountered a planet ran similarly to the Imperium, however refused to cooperate. The Blood Angels deployed planetwide and begun their attack only to discover the military occupants had genetically modified Warriors of their own.In essence, it was the Blood Angels vs Spartan 3 equivalents.The battle lasted a while and the Blood Angels, while not suffering too many losses. (80 Blood Angels were killed in the planet’s invasion) Were being given an impressive fight, which a few of them remarked including their primarch.After the first battle, the planetary leader & the Blood Angel’s primarch decided to call for a truce. I don’t remember what happened in detail but basically it turned out to be a trick and a bomb was planted on a Blood Angel’s ship and killed nearly 100 Blood Angels.Sanguinius then continued the invasion, this time allowing his legion to let loose. The Spartan like soldiers were ripped apart with the Space Marine’s bare hands and the planet’s resistance was slaughtered.In the end, the Blood Angels felt bad about what happened. They’d wish the planet had simply succumbed to the Imperium, the planet’s super soldiers would’ve made for a valuable war asset.Space Marines would definitely respect the likes of the Spartans. Especially the Spartan 2’s. However they would not allow their respect to blind them into showing mercy. They will fall, like all the rest.

Answer: I know I’ve written another answer to a very similar question, but this time I plan on giving the overview of each opponent, then giving my verdict and a quick fight, so please bear with me.SPARTAN II[Image from google]The standard Spartan IIs were considered demons by the enemies of the UNSC and saviors by its citizens. The S2s were augmented supersoldiers that could change the tide of battles.Strategy/experience:I know I’ve written another answer to a very similar question, but this time I plan on giving the overview of each opponent, then giving my verdict and a quick fight, so please bear with me.SPARTAN II[Image from google]The standard Spartan IIs were considered demons by the enemies of the UNSC and saviors by its citizens. The S2s were augmented supersoldiers that could change the tide of battles.Strategy/experience:Armor + Augmented abilities:Weapons:Overall Capabilities:ADEPTUS ASTARTES [Dark Angels chapter] (A tactical marine, NOT A PRIMARIS):The Emperor’s angels of death, the Adeptus Astartes (AKA space marines) are feared and revered across the Imperium, with single Astartes changing the outcome of entire campaigns. The Astartes are transhuman warriors who are genetically crafted to be the perfect weapons of the Imperium’s wrath.Strategies/Experience:Armor & Augmentations:Weapons & Equipment:Overall capabilities:Verdict:The Spartan IIs, while certainly being formidable supersoldiers of their universe, are simply not as powerful as the transhuman warriors that are the Adeptus Astartes. The enhancements, arms, armaments, and the experience of an average Tactical Marine outmatch the Spartan II in pretty much every aspect.Where a Spartan 2 would be overwhelmed by enemies, an Astartes would have already killed them; where a Spartan 2 could barely overwhelm a hunter in strength, an Astartes would be able to punch through the wall of a tank; where a Spartan 2 would speed blitz a group of enemies, an Astartes would have already killed them all. Where a Spartan 2 would die from loss of limbs, an Astartes wouldFight:Round 1:[Location: hanger of a Venator, with a few ruined starfighters & tanks lying around][There is a missile launcher beneath one of the ruins]Begin:Separated from his squad, the Spartan 2 continues onwards to the rendezvous point, making note of the destruction he sees as he approaches the hanger of this ship. As he enters the hanger, a bolter round slams into his chest, knocking him over and almost disabling his energy shield. Quickly, the Spartan roles behind nearby wreckage before popping back up, scanning his surroundings, and opening fire on the Astartes across the hanger. The extra second he took to find the Astartes was his undoing, however, as another bolter round strikes him in the head barely a second after he popped up.Knocked over again, and with his shields destroyed, the Spartan quickly recovers and hurls a grenade over the wreckage. As the explosion goes off, he dives out from behind his cover and opens fire again, only to be struck by another bolter round, which knocks him backward and destroys a large portion of the MJOLNIR armor on his torso. Quickly, the Spartan activates his bubble shield and looks around, seeing a missile launcher partially obscured under another nearby wreck. As three bolter rounds slam into the bubble shield (which still holds), the Spartan makes a dive for the missile launcher, only for a fourth round to slam into his chest, ending him instantly.The Astartes makes his way over to the fallen soldier and carefully picks up the bubble shield generator, before receiving new orders over the vox and dashing off to regroup with his squadron.Round 2:[Location: Jedi Temple hallway][Spartan Laser behind one pillar, Sniper rifle behind another]Begin:The Spartan jogs into the hallway and almost immediately dives behind one of the columns as a hail of bolder rounds flies past him. Returning fire from behind his cover, the Spartan’s AI notifies him of a Spartan Laser behind another one of the pillars as another round of bolter fire rips large chunks out of his cover. With practiced skill, the Spartan hurls a frag down the hall before making a dash for the pillar with the Spartan Laser. With equal skill, his own grenade is hurled right back at the pillar he was just standing behind, and a bolter round catches his left arm as he takes cover behind the new column, damaging his energy shield. As the Spartan picks up the Spartan Laser and begins to charge it, he hears what sounds like a brief series of clicking noises and the sound of something else being charged.As the Spartan prepares to aim and fire the Laser, a round from the Tactical Marine’s overcharged Plasma pistol obliterates both the column and the Spartan 2 himself, with only the legs of the Spartan remaining standing for a second before falling to the ground, lifeless.Round 3 (melee attempt):[Random sci-fi hallway][No other weapons]Begin:Both opponents appear at opposite ends of the hallway and both open fire immediately as the Space Marine charges forwards and the Spartan ducks back out of the opening. Bullets bounce harmlessly off of the Space Marine as he reaches the end of the hallway in mere seconds, catching the Spartan off guard. Quickly, the Marine punches with his fist, sending the Spartan flying backward and stunning him. In less than a second, the Marine draws his knife and lunges forward as the Spartan tries to regain his bearings. The Spartan manages to barely dodge the first knife blow, but not the Marine’s armored foot, which connects with the Spartan’s head, dealing massive trauma to the Spartan, who is almost killed outright. Quickly and lethally, so as not to waste ammo or dirty his knife, the Astartes stomps down on the Spartan’s now broken helmet and head, ending the fight instantly.Verdict part 2:As demonstrated, the Astartes overwhelmed the Spartan, who couldn’t move fast enough to use his smaller stature to his advantage and couldn’t take enough hits to deal out any lasting damage himself. The win clearly goes to the Adeptus Astartes.Sources:Warhammer 40k wikiHalo WikiGoogle [for the images]

Answer: The thirty-ought Space Marines all charge at once, absolutely massacre one Covenant army and die when the planet they're on gets glassed. The Covenant slowly but resolutely goomba-stomps the rest of humanity because there's no heroic supersoldiers to save the day. Subsequent generations of Covenant citizens look back on the conquest with patriotic pride and shudder when they think about that one battle with the thirty-ought giant batshit screaming humans who wrecked everyone's day and died unceremoniously.The thing about the Adeptus Astartes is that they're hyper-specialized for frontline combThe thirty-ought Space Marines all charge at once, absolutely massacre one Covenant army and die when the planet they're on gets glassed. The Covenant slowly but resolutely goomba-stomps the rest of humanity because there's no heroic supersoldiers to save the day. Subsequent generations of Covenant citizens look back on the conquest with patriotic pride and shudder when they think about that one battle with the thirty-ought giant batshit screaming humans who wrecked everyone's day and died unceremoniously.The thing about the Adeptus Astartes is that they're hyper-specialized for frontline combat. Everything about them - their gene seed, their armor, their weapons, their combat doctrine - is designed to dish out and tank as much damage as physically possible. They will stand in the meat grinder and unleash hell until the enemy is dead or they are. More often than not, it's the former.But the Human-Covenant war was more than a series of head-on charges. Sabotage, reconnaissance, assassination, guerilla warfare, infiltration, VIP extraction. These and more were just as common and often more important than frontline engagements. Missions like these required cunning, adaptability, versatility, subtlety. Spartans were all these things. Commandoes who could fill any role and do it better than anyone else. Space Marines, however, are 8-foot tall behemoths with guns the size of ponies who shake the earth with each step and scream dogma at their enemies. They aren't exactly built for subtlety. They would win every frontal assault. But the second you stuck one in one of the delicate black ops missions Spartans thrive at, he would fail miserably and probably get a plasma torpedo dropped on his head for the trouble.And that's just the ground stuff. Cycling out thirty Spartan-II's with thirty Astartes changes f*ck-all about the space engagements, which humanity was still cripplingly weak at. Even replacing all the II's, III's and Orions with Astartes wouldn't have mattered in the long run. Space Marines are devastatingly effective at a handful of things. But Spartans are extremely effective at a wide variety of things. And it's that versatility that made them so potent. It's that versatility that won the day in the long run.UPDATE 11/01/21"In ancient times, men built wonders, laid claim to the stars and sought to better themselves for the good of all. But we are much wiser now."Oh, the young and foolish. After nearly four more years down the 40k rabbit hole, this answer makes me want to relax in a Jacuzzi filled with burning promethium. Alright, time to fix this.Space marines outstrip Spartans in ability and equipment. They are eight foot tall gene warriors who spit acid and breathe vacuum and don’t care about arbitrary concepts like “gaping hole” and “missing limbs.” They’re clad in what could be described as a man-portable pillbox made of unobtanium that is designed to eat tank rounds and shrug off plasma. Their favorite weapons include an automatic RPG that turns armored opponents to mist and a chainsaw made of knives hard enough and sharp enough to chew through solid diamond. Despite being refrigerator-sized transhumans that weigh as much as two cows stacked on top of one another, space marines can move faster than the eye can process and can outrun an incoming missile. An Astartes would crack open a Spartan like a can of pringles, eat his head, digest his memories and use those memories to obtain the Spartan’s WiFi password.Basically, if a space marine acted the same way as a Spartan, he’d do it a hundred times better.But that’s the caveat: IF a space marine acted the same way as a Spartan. And this brings us to the Codex.The Codex Astartes, the military treatise that mandates how space marines organize and conduct themselves, can generally be regarded as the 40k equivalent to Spartan combat doctrine. It’s basically a mix of Art of War and the Holy Bible. Every space marine chapter has a different approach to adopting the Codex. Some, like the Ultramarines or Hammers of Dorn, hold the Codex as holy writ and adhere to it religiously. Others, like the Crimson Fists or Carcharodons, have a more liberal interpretation of the Codex and bend the rules as necessary. And there are some like the Black Templars and Space Wolves who have a passing respect for the Codex at best but otherwise ignore it entirely and do their own thing.The reason why the Codex is important is because it covers a lot of things but DOESN’T cover everything. And a lot of what it covers and mandates can be exceptionally well-planned and pragmatic or pants-on-head stupid and careless. So how a space marine behaves while filling in as a Spartan largely depends on the Codex compliance of his native chapter.An all-in chapter like the Ultramarines would be highly disciplined with a strategy for almost everything but would suffer from a crippling lack of improvisation when faced with something the Codex doesn’t account for, which is likely in Halo where a space marine is a fish out of water. Likely to do well until their first big trip-up, in which case they fail and fail hard.A dissonant chapter could theoretically be anything, but in the case of my two earlier examples (Black Templars and Space Wolves), they would actually be pretty similar to my 2018 description of space marines: melee-obsessed murdermachines who charge into the thick of it en masse and hack everything to pieces. Excellent shock troops, but with the exception of Space Wolf scouts, not at all accustomed to the roles Spartans are meant to take and likely to die in their first engagement without support from other military forces. Especially if they’re only thirty strong like Spartans are.Your best bet would be a chapter that obeys the Codex but doesn't follow it blindly. These would be adaptable and skilled, with a wide knowledge base and the ability to improvise as the situation demands. They can be scouts, saboteurs, assassins, commandos, shock troops: everything a Spartan needs to be. In this case, they could be the heroes humanity needs.Side note: don’t try to randomize marines from different chapters. Unless they have a unique system akin to the Deathwatch, it’ll be pure chaos. Space marine chapters are often so wildly different in culture and doctrine that there’d be little hope for cohesion. They could work together, but never with the same coordination as chapter brothers, let alone Spartans.

Answer: No.Space Marines are everything Spartans are & more.They’re taller, they’re stronger, they’re bulkier, they’re more durable, in some cases they’re faster.Let’s compare ballistics:The average Spartan weapon is the Assault Rifle, it fires a 7.62 caliber round and holds from 32 - 60 rounds per mag. An impressive rifle no doubt, I definitely wouldn’t wanna be shot by this thing.but it’s nothing compared to the Bolter.It fires a .75 caliber explosive kinetic rounds that detonate upon impact with a target. It is so big that most normal humans cannot wield it, let alone fire it.Let’s take an example:Continue ReadingNo.Space Marines are everything Spartans are & more.They’re taller, they’re stronger, they’re bulkier, they’re more durable, in some cases they’re faster.Let’s compare ballistics:The average Spartan weapon is the Assault Rifle, it fires a 7.62 caliber round and holds from 32 - 60 rounds per mag. An impressive rifle no doubt, I definitely wouldn’t wanna be shot by this thing.but it’s nothing compared to the Bolter.It fires a .75 caliber explosive kinetic rounds that detonate upon impact with a target. It is so big that most normal humans cannot wield it, let alone fire it.Let’s take an example:This Space Marine is carrying a heavy bolter, it’s like a bolter, butThe same gun requires a crew of 2 normal humans to effectively operate.Halo Spartans wield the same weaponry as the marines, normal calibers and normal sized weapons.Armor:While I don’t know the unique details involved in Mjolnir armor, we all know the suit enhances the Spartan’s physical feats. Making them stronger, faster, and all around more abled in combat. Same thing with Space Marines.However it is the durability I want to talk about. Of both the armor & the soldiers themselves.In Halo lore, Spartans are killed commonly by weapons considered weak by 40k standards. Plasma rifles, brute shots, plasma pistols, 7.62 rounds, .50 cals. Their armor is impressive. But weak by comparison.Space Marine armor is nearly impenetrable by small arms fire. Take the lasgun for instance.This rifle here can blow off limbs, explode body parts, and set you on fire. Powered up, it can punch through the most dense materials in the galaxy.This is considered weak by 40k standardsLasgun fire cannot penetrate space marine armor, see the image belowThis is a Space Marine literally standing still tanking dozens of shots while calmly firing his bolter back at the turret.Sum it up so far: In durability & ballistics, the Spartan is impressive for Halo. But stands no chance against Space Marines.I could stop here but I’m not going to.Now we must talk about reflexes, tactics, andWhen it comes to reflexes, Spartans are VERY fast. Space Marines are SLIGHTLY faster, literally SLAPPING BULLETS OUT OF THE AIR.When it comes to tactics, Spartans are used by the UNSC military as chess pieces. They take orders from common officers as attachments to regular platoons of marines.Space Marine chapters operate to their own accord. Oftentimes chapters will sendChaplin Grimaldus is placed in charge of an entire hive city. Monitoring everything from the readiness and positioning of city defenses, to the rations and guardsmen numbers within the city. He oversees it all for 9 days.And when it comes to melee, there is nothing the Spartan can do to compete with the marine. It’ll always end the same way.Your super soldiers are very impressive, Halo fans. However ours are simply better.But there’s a reason for that. Halo as a whole is a story about humanity trying to survive against the relentless onslaught of a superior foe. Spartans are made to give humanity a chance! Warhammer 40k isn’t about that at all. In Warhammer, humanity is the relentless onslaught. Space Marines are not realistic, they’re no dramatic, they’re made to be cool. And they are the coolest soldiers in any science fiction universe.

Answer: I program on a pretty cheap laptop, an ASUS that I paid $540 for. It’s perfectly adequate for Visual Studio Development, Eclipse and Jet Brains. I don’t feel hampered in the least. You can spend your money on a good IDE, though two good, free IDES’s are Eclipse and NetBeans. Laptops are commodities. I go through one about every two to three years. So I’m not going to buy a very expensive one that will be just as obsolete in a couple years as a cheap one.I would recommend a laptop running Windows ten with 500 GB disk and 8 GB memory. An Intel Core I5 is an adequate processor. A decent screen siI program on a pretty cheap laptop, an ASUS that I paid $540 for. You can spend your money on a good IDE, though two good, free IDES’s are Eclipse and NetBeans. Laptops are commodities. I go through one about every two to three years. So I’m not going to buy a very expensive one that will be just as obsolete in a couple years as a cheap one.I would recommend a laptop running Windows ten with 500 GB disk and 8 GB memory. Answer: If you are really interested in programming as a hobby then I would recommend looking at something like a Raspberry PI instead of a laptop.I learned to program back in the 80s when hardware was extremely limited. It wasn’t long until I would run into a physical limitation such as running out of memory or not having enough CPU.This was the moment where the fun really starts, where I needed to get creative and find solutions to really hard problems.Through this process I learned to have a much deeper understanding of the machine I was operating.The modern laptop is ridiculously overpowered. TherIf you are really interested in programming as a hobby then I would recommend looking at something like a Raspberry PI instead of a laptop.I learned to program back in the 80s when hardware was extremely limited. It wasn’t long until I would run into a physical limitation such as running out of memory or not having enough CPU.This was the moment where the fun really starts, where I needed to get creative and find solutions to really hard problems.Through this process I learned to have a much deeper understanding of the machine I was operating.The modern laptop is ridiculously overpowered. There seems to be a limitless supply of reaources. This means that modern coders seem to spend most of their time pursuing abstract goals instead of interacting with the physical machine.Starting with a stripped back machine like the PI will give you more of that old school experience. You will gain a greater appreciation for the machine itself.As you expand you can begin to creat PI networks instead of simply upgrading your laptop. This will expose you to the world of networking and parallel programming.You may also decide to reach out into the cloud and run virtual machines. You may even abandon machines and start using a serverless approach.You will be learning the skills that earn top dollar in today’s market. The budget will be $200.

Answer: There is no need to buy a super-fancy laptop.I often use $100 reconditioned laptops!What you need most is a couple of decent monitors - and a laptop (or desktop) computer that can drive them both at reasonable resolutions…plus a good, ergonomic keyboard and an actual mouse (not a touchpad).The computer almost doesn’t matter.Things get different when you have very specific KINDS of programming to do. So, for example, I do work on both Linux and Windows - so I have two computers and four monitors on my L-shaped desk…my biggest need isn’t a better computer - it’s a bigger desk!But if you get heavThere is no need to buy a super-fancy laptop.I often use $100 reconditioned laptops!What you need most is a couple of decent monitors - and a laptop (or desktop) computer that can drive them both at reasonable resolutions…plus a good, ergonomic keyboard and an actual mouse (not a touchpad).The computer almost doesn’t matter.Things get different when you have very specific KINDS of programming to do. So, for example, I do work on both Linux and Windows - so I have two computers and four monitors on my L-shaped desk…my biggest need isn’t a better computer - it’s a bigger desk!But if you get heavily into graphics work - you’ll want something with a really good graphics card.You might also want to be sure you have LOTS of disk space.

Answer: For anything you’re coding as an individual and compiling, it should compile in a flash on even a low end machine. Not much processing power required. It’s only when you start compiling millions of lines of code, with an intricate multi-project build with hundreds of files, are you going to really need something high performance to build your content.Money would be better spent buying a couple 27″ monitors, a basic laptop that will drive two monitors. A good quality keyboard and mouse. Don’t cheap out on the RAM get at least 8GB but preferably 16GB. You can find many laptops that meet the needFor anything you’re coding as an individual and compiling, it should compile in a flash on even a low end machine. Not much processing power required. It’s only when you start compiling millions of lines of code, with an intricate multi-project build with hundreds of files, are you going to really need something high performance to build your content.Money would be better spent buying a couple 27″ monitors, a basic laptop that will drive two monitors. A good quality keyboard and mouse. Don’t cheap out on the RAM get at least 8GB but preferably 16GB. You can find many laptops that meet the needs < $1000, and some good quality monitors in the $150-$200 range (ea)If you get serious into coding, you don’t want to be starring at it on a tiny laptop screen. And you want two screens as there will be times when you’re wanting to look at code from multiple sources at a time, or having reference information up at the same time.

Answer: $2000 is way more than you need.My normal programming laptop is a little too big and heavy to be comfortably portable, but it’s super-powerful and cheap: Dell Precision M4600. Get one on eBay that has 1080p and a quad-core i7 for maybe $350. That money would get you a good disk and 16GB of RAM.It would also get you Windows 10, most likely, and don’t throw that away, but make sure the disk is big enough that you can also install Ubuntu Linux on it, and then learn your coding on that.The Precision of this class (from about 2011) can take an SSD in the mini-PCI slot in addition to a SATA HDD or S$2000 is way more than you need.My normal programming laptop is a little too big and heavy to be comfortably portable, but it’s super-powerful and cheap: Dell Precision M4600. Get one on eBay that has 1080p and a quad-core i7 for maybe $350. That money would get you a good disk and 16GB of RAM.It would also get you Windows 10, most likely, and don’t throw that away, but make sure the disk is big enough that you can also install Ubuntu Linux on it, and then learn your coding on that.The Precision of this class (from about 2011) can take an SSD in the mini-PCI slot in addition to a SATA HDD or SSD. I’d recommend doing so, about $100 for a 256GB PCI one.If you need portability, there are other options, but this is, I believe, about the most bang for the buck you can get in a laptop today. The M4800 series is better, and can drive a 4K external display, but everyone knows it, so it costs a lot more.
